pages.title: Culture
pages.quote: Visitors to UCLA Lab School are impressed by how articulate students are in describing their own learning processes. That lack of shame in incomplete mastery does not happen by accident. It is a matter of teachers managing the face threat potential of engaging students at the leading edge of their capacity, or in the zone of proximal development.
pages.citation: Adapted from Erickson, F., with Bagrodia, R., Cook-Sather, A., Espinoza, M., Jurow, S., Shultz, J. and Spencer, J. (2007). Students' Experience of School Curriculum: The Everyday Circumstances of Granting and Withholding Assent to Learn. In Connelly, F.M. et al (eds.), The Sage Handbook of Curriculum. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications, Inc., pp. 198-218.
pages.more: An effective classroom ecosystem is one in which teachers and students work together with mutual respect and as active participants in the learning process. Teachers facilitate active learning by providing opportunities for children to work in a variety of social arrangements; by modeling respect for ideas, encouraging questions, and valuing mistakes as part of learning; and by fostering children's independent use of resources to construct knowledge.

pages.title: Student-Student Culture
pages.definition: Children should be able to trust that they can work with their classmates in a socially safe environment. They should be able to avoid embarrassment, work without interference from other students when they wish to do so, and at other times work cooperatively with students, getting and giving help to one another in a timely way. Children should be given opportunities to work in a variety of configurations: individually, in pairs, in small groups of four or five, and as a whole group. Each configuration provides different opportunities to develop independence or to share work, negotiate ideas and conflicts, actively listen to other perspectives and develop relationships.
pages.benefits: Working together in conditions of mutual respect enriches children's personal relationships and improves verbal and nonverbal communication skills. When children work in a group they must be able to articulate their ideas without fear of harsh criticism or mockery from their fellow students. This candor helps students to deepen their understanding of concepts, which enhances their cognitive development. As children communicate about their thinking, they learn to speak in relationship to listening, and listen in relationship to speaking. In this way they challenge each others' thinking, with consideration for others, thus developing positive social skills.
pages.examples: In a large group, children discuss whether they should build their roller coaster inside or outside the classroom. The teacher acts as a facilitator while the children exchange ideas and concerns about the roller coaster's location. Children become invested in the process because they are given the opportunity to make decisions and come up with solutions.

video.title: The Roller Coaster

planningPoints.text: When the children came up with the idea to build a roller coaster, the teachers did project planning to ensure that there would be many opportunities for learning about the science concepts and big ideas.
In their project planning, teachers asked families to contribute scrap materials for use in building the roller coaster.

Part of the planning process was to group children into committees. These two students volunteered for the Building Committee. Committees are a good way to incorporate small-group work into class projects, and they mirror practices used in the adult workplace.

setupPoints.text: Teachers and children work on the roller coaster outside. Using outdoor space extends the learning environment and allows teachers and small groups to engage in detailed, concentrated work with fewer distractions.

Students and teachers chose to mount the roller coaster in a space where they can have easy, on-going access to it. This allows them to make revisions as needed and helps create an on-going dialogue about the project and the concepts.
The materials for the project are varied and accessible to all the children. The teacher encourages the children to decide which materials will work best for their purpose.
The materials include a jumble of donated scraps. Using donated and found materials keeps project costs low and inspires children to use creativity and imagination.

culturePoints.text: Although a teacher is present to supervise, the children are trusted to work on testing and improving the model roller coaster the group is building. They are able to work independently and productively because the teachers have set up routines to support this and children have had much practice working together.
Notice that the task requires the children to work cooperatively to solve the problem of how to get the ball through the tube. Real work in the world requires collaboration.

Notice how the children negotiate ideas, making suggestions and in turn being open to suggestions. Again, this kind of cooperative work is made possible by giving children many opportunities to work together.
The task engages the children and sustains their interest because it is in the context of a project they and their peers have generated.

exPoints.text: Working with a 3-D model provides children with firsthand experiences that make the concepts more tangible. Here the children can observe firsthand the effects of force and motion and the operation of simple machines such as inclined planes.

The students' building and testing of the roller coaster model is informed by previous experiences designed to illustrate the concepts. It also will provide context and help deepen understanding as they continue to explore the concepts and big ideas.

repPoints.text: The model roller coaster is a 3-D representation of concepts such as 'force causes motion and simple machines make work easier'.

Before beginning construction of the roller coaster, the children created 2-D representations of the components, such as inclined planes. In their drawings and paintings the children recorded their observations and then used those observations to inform the building of their 3-D representations.

The students' testing leads to observations about what makes sections of the roller coaster function, and this in turn leads to revisions to the model. Revising their 3-D representations allows children to deepen their understanding and formulate new questions.

video.description: During their study of simple machines, force and motion, and kinetic and potential energy, students decided to build a roller coaster that sends messages from one classroom to another. In this video, two children are working on the roller coaster model.
video.standards:
The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background.
  2. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time.
  3. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull.
  4. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move.
  5. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

enrich.intro: Before developing Student-Student Culture, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: The classroom space supports the variety of ways that children learn
Teachers trust children to work in small groups without adult guidance
list.more: Giving children opportunities to work with peers and to manage their own learning helps them become more engaged in the work and more likely to gain deep understanding of the concepts. To help ensure that the small groups are successful, teachers need to set up clear expectations for how children work together, and they need to communicate these expectations early and often.

list.text: Frequent conversations encourage differing perspectives and ideas
list.more: Discussion and negotiation help children make sense of the concepts, the big ideas and the learning experiences. As children talk to one another they have natural opportunities to question and explain, to sort out what they do and do not understand and to revise their thinking. This active processing of ideas makes the content more memorable and engaging for students. It also helps students develop work and social skills that will be useful throughout their lives.

challenges.theText:
How can I be sure students are learning if there is no teacher or adult at a table?
The classroom-ecosystem approach to teaching and learning is based on the belief that children are naturally curious and capable of learning independently.
To help ensure that the learning goals are met, set up experiences and materials that are engaging for children and have purpose. Everything on the table should be connected to the concepts and big ideas.
The way teachers put out materials is also important. For example, provide tools such as magnifying glasses to accompany experiences. Set out books with intriguing photos to help children in their research. Make sure there are sharpened pencils and different types of paper for children to use. Inviting materials help engage children in the learning experiences and encourage them to record their ideas and their understanding.
When is there time in the day for conversation and discussion? How do I best facilitate them?
Children need to have opportunities throughout the day to share their work with the teacher and each other and to discuss their hypotheses, predictions and thoughts for further study. This is when critical thinking and deep learning happen.
After each work time hold a debriefing. Follow firsthand, secondhand and thirdhand experiences and any kind of representation of understanding with a conversation. These conversations can be one-on-one with a teacher or involve the whole group. Whenever possible, include time for both types of discussion.
The best way to facilitate conversation is through asking open-ended questions and allowing children to answer without fear of judgment. For example, ask children: What did you notice? How did this thing compare to that one? What are some things that are similar, different? What if we were to add this? What do you predict will happen? How can you record what happened?
Conversations are most effective when the class is gathered in a common space, such as on the rug, rather than in desks or in rows of chairs. Sitting together in a circle on the rug helps make clear that everyone is a potential contributor and everyone's contribution is valued.
How do I encourage students who have a hard time participating in discussions?
Each child has something valuable and important to offer the learning community. It's important for teachers to unlock that gift, to find a child's strengths and what really interests her or him. This takes a lot of listening to and observing children, but it pays off in richer, fuller class discussions and deeper understanding of the concepts for all the children. If a child is quiet or reticent, put him in charge of a project he can share and feel proud of. Facilitate conversations so not only the same children are answering. Give quieter children time to answer. Modeling a respectful way to converse helps everyone learn how to be part of a productive work group.
What are some ways to build "community" in my classroom?
Setting up reasonable expectations for behavior and making sure children know what those expectations are helps build a community where everyone takes responsibility for himself or herself and everyone takes on the role of contributor.
In the beginning of the year and throughout the year, talk to children about taking care of their learning environment and keeping it beautiful. Emphasize that each person is an integral part of that. Build in lessons about how to take care of materials by putting caps on markers, cleaning up paintbrushes, putting away supplies, etc.
Model respect for children to help ensure that they will respect you and the other adults and children in the classroom. Even small things such as speaking to children warmly and with respect for their intelligence, displaying their work without added adornment, and giving them the time they need to complete tasks or answer questions help create a constructive community.

pages.title: Teacher-Student Culture
pages.definition: Children should be able to trust that they can work comfortably with their teacher in the presence of their fellow students. They should be able to avoid embarrassment as they interact with their teacher, work without interruption when that is appropriate, ask for help from the teacher, and get help in a timely way, when they need it. The teacher's role in the classroom ecosystem is one of active listener, facilitator of ideas and researcher.
pages.benefits: When the social arrangement of the classroom as a workplace for learning is one in which children feel safe to ask questions and take intellectual risks they become deeper thinkers and more invested learners. Addressing children's individual needs, integrating their ideas into instruction, and encouraging questions helps all children feel they have a contribution to make. As children see their ideas becoming an important part of classroom life, they feel invested in the classroom community and are more open and ready to take on new learning. They develop strong learning morale.
pages.examples: To assess a student's understanding of a concept, the teacher asks him to explain his reasoning. During the course of his explanation, the child realizes that he doesn't quite understand and he begins to question his reasoning. Rather than criticizing the child for being "wrong" or telling him the "right" answer, the teacher allows the student time to explain his thinking and helps to scaffold his understanding through inquiry.

video.title: Alex Being Forthright - and Mistaken

planningPoints.text: The idea to build a roller coaster was generated by the children. The teachers did careful planning to align the project with the concepts and big ideas.

The teacher planned this time to work with a small group of students to assess their understanding of the concepts of kinetic and potential energy. Meanwhile, a teaching assistant and a parent volunteer work with the other children on another aspect of the roller coaster project.

After realizing the students in the small group were confused about the concepts, the teacher brought the discussion to the whole group. This required flexibility in planning and a willingness to allow the children's needs to influence the course of instruction.
After this discussion, the teacher will do additional planning with her colleagues to clarify her own understanding of the scientific concepts and determine how best to clarify them for the students.

setupPoints.text: When setting up a large project, consider all aspects of the learning environment. Using outdoor space, when possible, provides opportunities for small group work and allows for in-depth, uninterrupted discussion.

Throughout the work space, resources are accessible to all the children. Note the canisters of building materials on the countertop. When the camera zooms out, notice the paint bottles to the left of the sink and the materials in storage tables at the far right. These important supplies are stored at children's height and are available as they need them.

The roller coaster is mounted on the outside of the classroom windows and remains there for the duration of the project. Displaying on-going work helps stimulate thinking, creativity and discussion, and integrates the project into the life of the classroom.

Notice the photos displayed behind the roller coaster. They tell the story of the project thus far. Displaying documentation of the group's planning and thinking process provides context for the project, gives teachers and children opportunities for reflection, and offers parents a way to connect with the children's work.

Student work, including paintings depicting force and motion, is displayed prominently in the classroom. The displays help stimulate thinking, create dialogue and convey that the children's work is valued.

culturePoints.text: Notice the teacher's request: "Alex, you gotta explain that." Without a lot of prior work on making it safe to say what you think when the teacher asks, this request would be intimidating to a child.

Notice that Alex is comfortable expressing his ideas. Although he is slightly wrong about the concepts, discussing them will help him refine his understanding and work toward a notion of potential energy being gained or lost as it trades off with kinetic energy (energy of motion).

The teacher realizes there is something that doesn't add up, but she doesn't tell the child he's wrong or correct him. Instead she tries to help him clarify his understanding by engaging him in dialogue.

Now the child realizes he isn't right, but he is still being candid. Although the stakes for embarassment are higher, he still says what he thinks. An effective classroom culture values learning as a process and allows children to revise their thinking through discussion and interaction.

Note that the teacher could have let the misconception pass, but she doesn't. Because she has established the classroom as a socially safe environment, she knows she can engage the whole group in the discussion.

Alex is saying that the message ball is gaining kinetic energy when it is going down. Notice he is still willing to share his ideas openly, even when he is in front of the whole class. Notice, too, that everyone is respectful as he speaks.

Here the teacher has noticed another child has something to say. Together the teacher and children construct a discussion in which children say what they think and no one attacks their ideas or pokes fun. The clear message is that the classroom is a safe place where thoughts can be expressed without negative consequences.

Notice how the teacher picks up on the child's question, "When it's going down it's going faster. So how is it losing speed?" When the teacher says, "That's confusing," she underscores the dissonance between the ideas and models how to think through a problem
As discussions and re-teaching continue, the teacher will use what the children are saying to distinguish between speed and total energy and between kinetic and potential energy.

For more about the story of the roller coaster, go to the Flexible Planning video, which shows how the teachers did research to clarify their understanding of kinetic and potential energy and then brought the information to the children.

exPoints.text: The children began building the roller coaster toward the end of the school year, but they had been building knowledge of the concepts since September. For example, a trip to a local amusement park allowed the children to explore the concepts of force and motion and kinetic and potential energy through firsthand experiences with roller coasters.
The students have firsthand experiences as they use the roller coaster model to apply their knowledge of the concepts.

The children are able to discuss scientific ideas because they have had many experiences throughout the year that were designed to familiarize them with the concepts. These included building and testing model inclined planes and experimenting with simple machines.

repPoints.text: Using their knowledge of the concepts, the students have built a 3-D working model of a roller coaster.  A student uses text to label the roller coaster where he thinks kinetic and potential energy are at work.

As the student explains his reasoning for labeling the parts of the roller coaster, he finds he is confused about the concepts. Having children talk about their work is an excellent way to assess their understanding and provides an opportunity to clarify the concepts.
Notice the paintings displayed above and to the right of the white board. They are 2-D representations of the children's understanding of force and motion.

Giving children the opportunity to represent their thinking in different ways (i.e., orally, by drawing and painting, and by building a 3-D model) helps children understand the 'how, what' and 'why' of a concept. It also offers multiple entry points to accommodate different learning styles.

video.description: In the sequence before this video begins, the teacher had asked children to label their roller coaster at the points where the ball achieves maximum kinetic and potential energy. When Alex explains his placement of the labels, it becomes apparent that he is confusing velocity with the distinction between kinetic and potential energy. The teacher recognizes this and makes a plan to help him refine his understanding. (For more on how she and her colleague re-teach the concepts to clear up the misconceptions, go to the Example Video in Flexible Planning.)
video.concept: Energy is stored and energy is released
video.standards: The concepts here go beyond the standards, but it was important to address them because they came up in the context of the project.

enrich.intro: Before developing Student-Student Culture, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: Frequent conversations encourage differing perspectives and ideas
Teachers actively listen to children's ideas and emergent thinking
list.more:
Active listening on the part of the teacher encourages children to express their ideas. It helps children develop confidence and empowers them to take an active role in the learning process. This sets up a different kind of relationship in the classroom, one that is less focused on the teacher imparting knowledge and more on teachers and students working together to construct knowledge.
When teachers take the time to listen to children's ideas they get to know their students better and see their potential and their individuality. Strong knowledge of their students helps teachers become better at assessing learning and is a key factor in children's academic success.

list.text: Teachers see themselves as researchers and facilitators of children's learning
The classroom space is comfortable and sparks children's curiosity
list.more: Providing children with a comfortable, inviting physical environment lets them know that they are valued and encourages their cooperative participation in the learning community. An attractive, functional space in which children can easily access resources and work both independently and cooperatively invites them to engage with the concepts and big ideas. When the physical environment is safe and inviting, opportunities emerge for children to share their ideas and understanding with one another and to learn through their interactions with teachers and peers.

list.text: Teachers display student work without embellishments

challenges.theText:
How can I be sure students are learning if there is no teacher or adult at a table?
The classroom-ecosystem approach to teaching and learning is based on the belief that children are naturally curious and capable of learning independently.
To help ensure that the learning goals are met, set up experiences and materials that are engaging for children and have purpose. Everything on the table should be connected to the concepts and big ideas.
The way teachers put out materials is also important. For example, provide tools such as magnifying glasses to accompany experiences. Set out books with intriguing photos to help children in their research. Make sure there are sharpened pencils and different types of paper for children to use. Inviting materials help engage children in the learning experiences and encourage them to record their ideas and their understanding.
When is there time in the day for conversation and discussion? How do I best facilitate them?
Children need to have opportunities throughout the day to share their work with the teacher and each other and to discuss their hypotheses, predictions and thoughts for further study. This is when critical thinking and deep learning happen.
After each work time hold a debriefing. Follow firsthand, secondhand and thirdhand experiences and any kind of representation of understanding with a conversation. These conversations can be one-on-one with a teacher or involve the whole group. Whenever possible, include time for both types of discussion.
The best way to facilitate conversation is through asking open-ended questions and allowing children to answer without fear of judgment. For example, ask children: What did you notice? How did this thing compare to that one? What are some things that are similar, different? What if we were to add this? What do you predict will happen? How can you record what happened?
Conversations are most effective when the class is gathered in a common space, such as on the rug, rather than in desks or in rows of chairs. Sitting together in a circle on the rug helps make clear that everyone is a potential contributor and everyone's contribution is valued.
How do I encourage students who have a hard time participating in discussions?
Each child has something valuable and important to offer the learning community. It's important for teachers to unlock that gift, to find a child's strengths and what really interests her or him. This takes a lot of listening to and observing children, but it pays off in richer, fuller class discussions and deeper understanding of the concepts for all the children. If a child is quiet or reticent, put him in charge of a project he can share and feel proud of. Facilitate conversations so not only the same children are answering. Give quieter children time to answer. Modeling a respectful way to converse helps everyone learn how to be part of a productive work group.
What are some ways to build "community" in my classroom?
Setting up reasonable expectations for behavior and making sure children know what those expectations are helps build a community where everyone takes responsibility for himself or herself and everyone takes on the role of contributor.
In the beginning of the year and throughout the year, talk to children about taking care of their learning environment and keeping it beautiful. Emphasize that each person is an integral part of that. Build in lessons about how to take care of materials by putting caps on markers, cleaning up paintbrushes, putting away supplies, etc.
Model respect for children to help ensure that they will respect you and the other adults and children in the classroom. Even small things such as speaking to children warmly and with respect for their intelligence, displaying their work without added adornment, and giving them the time they need to complete tasks or answer questions help create a constructive community.

pages.title: Experiences
pages.quote: A multiplicity of our five senses, the only avenues into the brain, are activated through firsthand experiences.
pages.citation:
Lowery, L. (1998).
The Biological Basis of Thinking and Learning (Monograph), p. 18
Berkeley, CA: Lawrence Hall of Science.
pages.more: Before children can formulate questions or show what they know, they have to be provided with experiences related to the content. Once children have been provided background knowledge either through firsthand or secondhand experiences, they are ready to work with text, which both uses and deepens prior knowledge. The goal in providing children with a variety of experiences is to help them move from novice to expert in their understanding and their ability to apply their knowledge of the concepts.

pages.title: Firsthand Experiences
pages.definition: Firsthand experiences are concrete. They are learning opportunities that involve participation through our five senses.
pages.benefits: Firsthand experiences provide children opportunities to connect prior knowledge with newly acquired knowledge and to apply learning to their everyday lives. They also offer opportunities for interactions to stimulate inquiry and discussions and incentive to research and learn more.
pages.examples: For firsthand experiences with force and motion, the teacher takes the children to the playground. Using the slide, monkey bars and swings helps children see how forces such as pushes, pulls, gravity and friction create motion.

video.title: Simple Machines Make Work Easier

planningPoints.text: At first the teacher does not give the children the proper tools to make their work easier. Instead she has planned the experience so that children can discover firsthand how difficult it is to perform the task without simple machines.
The teacher has chosen materials that illustrate the concept that simple machines make work easier. She provides a variety of materials and tools, such as clay, wood, hammers, nails and rolling pins.

setupPoints.text: The students' work is completed in small groups, where they can hear and see each others' activities.
The tools are in a central place where all children can access them without assistance.
The book on the table provides a ready source of information about simple machines that children can easily access.
In both classrooms, teachers make use of the entire space, setting up small groups at tables and allowing children to move around as they pursue their work.

culturePoints.text: Working together in small groups, the children share their experiences and their observations.
Notice that the teacher sits with the children, at their level, so he can engage them in conversation about their work.

Notice that the children are trusted to use tools such as hammers and nails, and they use them responsibly. This is possible because the teachers have established routines to accustom children to working independently.

exPoints.text: First children are asked to work with wood and nails using only their hands.

Next, the children will be given the opportunity to experience using tools to make work easier. As the children are beginning, the teacher will focus them on the task by reminding them of the concept.
After the children have had the experience, the teacher will remind them again of the concept. Both the work assigned and the teacher's commentary ask the children to be explicit about the concept.

repPoints.text: The student uses text and drawing to represent her understanding that simple machines require less energy than doing the same task manually.
The teacher talks with the student to help her reflect on the experience and link it to the concepts.

video.description: The students are first asked to complete a set of tasks using only their hands. Then they are asked to complete the same tasks using small tools. This experience provides background knowledge on simple machines and how they make work easier.
video.standards:
The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull.
  2. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move.
  3. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

enrich.intro: Before developing Student-Student Culture, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It connects to children's prior knowledge
list.more: On the playground, students experience force and motion firsthand. Although they have used the monkey bars many times before, they now have a specific intent, which is to create a motion using the push and pull of their bodies as a force.

list.text: It builds on previously taught concepts
It involves a group discussion
It is something the children suggest
list.more: After engaging in a variety of firsthand experiences the teacher had planned, the children looked around the playground for their own examples of how force creates motion. They observed that pushing the knob on the drinking fountain forced the water to come out.

list.text: Children record their findings

challenges.theText:
My yearly classroom budget allows for only one field trip. How can I assure that my students get a variety of firsthand experiences?
If field trips are not possible, finding creative ways to bring the experience into your classroom is the next best thing. For example, if your students are studying the rock cycle and a trip to the mountains to collect different kinds of rocks can't be arranged, bringing in igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks for the children to observe is helpful. If it's not possible to visit a garden to witness pollination firsthand, growing a small garden that attracts pollinators in or around your classroom is also meaningful.
Should I provide a firsthand experience for every new concept?
Firsthand experiences should be used whenever possible. They provide children opportunities to connect prior knowledge with newly acquired knowledge and to apply learning to their everyday lives. However, it is not always possible to have children dissect an insect, observe a whale in its natural habitat or go for a walk to view a tree's varied-colored leaves. In this case, age-appropriate videos, photographs and text can and should be used.
Where can I get quality expository science texts for young children?
The library media teacher at your school or the children's librarian at your local public library can recommend books and point you to other resources.
In addition, the following web sites publish lists of outstanding science books for children.
http://www.sbfonline.com/prizes.htmAnnual prize winners for excellence in science books, chosen by Science Books and Film (SB and F), a critical review journal devoted exclusively to print and non-print materials in all the sciences and for all age groups. SB and F is published by the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS).http://www.nsta.org/publications/ostb/default.aspxTitles on this annotated list are chosen because they are "accurate and interesting and have a spark of inspiration that will challenge and extend the reader." Sponsored by the Australian Academy of Science.

pages.title: Secondhand Experiences
pages.definition: Secondhand experiences are offered through visuals such as a video, a photograph or a poster, or through observation of a demonstration or experiment.
pages.benefits: A visual representation of the content helps students gain a more immediate connection than text alone. It also gives students more information and makes the material more memorable.
pages.examples: To show students what molecules look like in a liquid, a solid and a gas, the teacher shows students a poster or a photograph. This visual representation offers information about content for which firsthand experiences are not available.

video.title: Rocks, Sand and Awesome Scientists

planningPoints.text: The teacher has structured the introduction of the concepts so that children first made predictions and now are engaging in a secondhand experience. This helps give the children an investment in the experiment as they watch to see how their predictions compare to the results.

setupPoints.text: The group sits in a circle, which encourages discussion and interaction.
The demonstration uses simple and inexpensive materials--rocks, sand, marbles, water and glass jars.
The children are encouraged to move around the space and to position themselves so they can closely observe the rocks and water.

culturePoints.text: As the teacher conducts the experiment, she asks the children to share their ideas and observations. Fostering a classroom culture in which students are expected to take turns and to listen actively and respectfully encourages participation.

Notice that the teacher refers back to the child's comment, mentioning him by name. In an effective classroom ecosystem, teachers and children are partners in the learning process and build off each others' ideas.

Notice that the children are free to sit comfortably, and some even lie on the floor. Well established routines and expectations for behavior make it possible for the group to work in this way. By encouraging children to move around so they can see, the teacher helps deepen the children's engagement in the experience.

exPoints.text: The teacher gathers the children for a secondhand experience, which helps make the science concepts more memorable because they can see the way the physical principles play out.
The teacher asks lots of questions to engage children's attention and focus the experience on the concepts.
Asking "What's happening?" cues the children to observe closely and helps them develop analytical skills.

The animation in the teacher's voice helps engage the children in the secondhand experience. In secondhand experiences, teachers have to work harder to summon children's attention. This is different from firsthand experiences, where the tension is built into the experience.

repPoints.text: Before the demonstration, the teacher asked the children to predict what would happen and to create 2-D representations of their thinking.

Notice how the child refers to his drawing and says, "That's what I did." Children have their 2-D representations in front of them and can refer to them as they watch the experiment and make observations.

video.description: To illustrate the concept "matter takes up space," the teacher gathers a small group of children for a demonstration, a secondhand experience.
video.standards:
Materials come in different forms (states), including solids, liquids, and gases. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know solids, liquids, and gases have different properties.
  2. Students know the properties of substances can change when the substances are mixed, cooled, or heated.

enrich.intro: Before developing Student-Student Culture, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: Videos, posters and photographs are age-appropriate
list.more: This poster showing wheels and axels is appropriate for young children because the drawings are visually simple yet serious. In contrast, cartoon-like drawings discount children's intelligence and capabilities. The poster also includes symbols, such as arrows, that depict movement. Students are often asked to use symbols to show movement in their 2-D representations.

list.text: Videos, posters and photographs spark children's curiosity
list.more: A poster of Leonardo da Vinci's design for a giant catapult and a photo of the Wright brothers' first motored flight help stimulate children's curiosity and promote discussion and conversation. These kinds of visuals honor children's intelligence and capabilities.

pages.title: Thirdhand Experiences
pages.definition: Thirdhand experiences involve narrative and expository texts.
pages.benefits: Because young children are inherently curious about the world, we have the responsibility to provide them with books whose purpose is to convey information. These texts give children the opportunity to use their background knowledge to develop a more profound understanding of the concepts and can be both visually exciting and intellectually stimulating.
pages.examples: The teacher first gives the students multiple opportunities to experiment with changing a liquid to a solid and vice versa. After these firsthand experiences, the children read informational texts about liquids and solids.

video.title: What is the World Made Of?

planningPoints.text: In her planning, the teacher decided to read the book between firsthand and secondhand experiences to both reinforce and foreshadow the experiences. In this case, she's using the book to help focus on the scientific lexicon of the states of matter.
The teacher does an initial assessment of the students' background knowledge of gas as one of the states of matter.

setupPoints.text: With thirdhand experiences it is possible to gather children in larger groups. However, it is necessary to work harder to focus children's attention. The animation in the teacher's voice helps engage the children in the thirdhand experience.
The whole-group area is large enough for two classrooms to sit together comfortably. This was achieved by pushing away some of the furniture temporarily.

culturePoints.text: Bringing the children together in a large group allows them to share their experiences and knowledge as they discuss the book. Later, when they work in small groups, they can refer back to their shared experience of the story.

The teacher uses questions to engage the children in the story and focus their attention on the crucial information at the right moments. Having the children assist in reading the material helps reinforce their understanding of the concept.

exPoints.text: The teacher uses a thirdhand experience, reading a book about the states of matter, to reinforce what the children have learned through firsthand experiences.

The animation in the teacher's voice helps engage the children in the thirdhand experience. In thirdhand experiences teachers have to work harder to summon children's attention. This is different from firsthand experiences, where the tension is built into the experience.
To highlight and bring attention to the concepts and the scientific lexicon, the teacher uses inflection and asks the children questions.

Although the concept of gas as one of the states of matter has been introduced through a thirdhand experience, the students have a frame of reference from the many firsthand experiences they have had with solids and liquids.

repPoints.text: With the exception of the teacher inviting children to call out words, children are not creating representations here. Their learning and practicing the scientific lexicon will support their later representation.

video.description: Two K-1 classrooms, one bilingual and one monolingual, gather to listen to a reading about the different states of matter.
video.standards:
Properties of materials can be observed, measured, and predicted. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know water can be a liquid or a solid and can be made to change back and forth from one form to the other.

Materials come in different forms (states), including solids, liquids, and gases. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know solids, liquids, and gases have different properties.

enrich.intro: Before developing Thirdhand Experiences, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: Texts include fiction and non-fiction related to the science concepts
list.more:
A variety of fiction and nonfiction texts are available to help children deepen their understanding of the concepts. Teachers can talk to their school library teacher or local public librarian for suggestions. There are also organizations that publish yearly lists of outstanding science books.
See Best Books for Children or Outstanding Science Trade Books for Students K-12.

list.text: Books related to science concepts have a space in the classroom
list.more: A selection of engaging and age-appropriate fiction and nonfiction texts are set out where they will invite curiosity and children have easy access to them.

My yearly classroom budget allows for only one field trip. How can I assure that my students get a variety of firsthand experiences?
If field trips are not possible, finding creative ways to bring the experience into your classroom is the next best thing. For example, if your students are studying the rock cycle and a trip to the mountains to collect different kinds of rocks can't be arranged, bringing in igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks for the children to observe is helpful. If it's not possible to visit a garden to witness pollination firsthand, growing a small garden that attracts pollinators in or around your classroom is also meaningful.

Firsthand experiences should be used whenever possible. They provide children opportunities to connect prior knowledge with newly acquired knowledge and to apply learning to their everyday lives. However, it is not always possible to have children dissect an insect, observe a whale in its natural habitat or go for a walk to view a tree's varied-colored leaves. In this case, age-appropriate videos, photographs and text can and should be used.
Where can I get quality expository science texts for young children?
The library media teacher at your school or the children's librarian at your local public library can recommend books and point you to other resources.
In addition, the following web sites publish lists of outstanding science books for children.
http://www.sbfonline.com/prizes.htmAnnual prize winners for excellence in science books, chosen by Science Books and Film (SB and F), a critical review journal devoted exclusively to print and non-print materials in all the sciences and for all age groups. SB and F is published by the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS).http://www.nsta.org/publications/ostb/default.aspxTitles on this annotated list are chosen because they are "accurate and interesting and have a spark of inspiration that will challenge and extend the reader." Sponsored by the Australian Academy of Science.

pages.title: Representation
pages.quote: Different forms of representation evoke, develop, and refine the modes of thinking that contribute to the cultivation of what is broadly called mind... By no means is thinking limited to what words alone can carry.
pages.citation:
Eisner, E. (December 2003/January 2004).
Preparing for Today and Tomorrow,
Educational Leadership, p. 6
pages.more:
Representation is the means by which students demonstrate and communicate their knowledge of big ideas and concepts both to the teacher and to themselves. Students create representations in a variety of ways, including drawing, writing, graphing, sculpting and movement. This work can be categorized into four key formats--oral/textual, kinesthetic, two-dimensional and three-dimensional--each of which offers unique opportunities for children to deepen their understanding. (See General Guidelines for Choosing a Representational Format)

Deep understanding of a concept includes knowing about its structure, its behavior and its function, or the "what," the "how," and the "why" of the concept. For example, to understand the concept "Simple machines make work easier," students must know what are the different parts of the simple machine (structure), how the simple machine works (behavior) and why it makes work easier (function). One type of representation may help students see the "what" while another may help them see the "how."

Additionally, asking children to create multiple representations of concepts and big ideas helps them to synthesize and build knowledge. Offering opportunities to represent concepts in a variety of ways helps to ensure that children with differences in learning style, previous experiences and background knowledge will be engaged and invested in the learning process. At the same time, representation provides important tools for assessing children's understanding and allows the teacher to make informed decisions about instruction. The result is greater effectiveness in addressing children's individual learning needs, which ultimately helps ensure academic success for every child.

pages.title: 2-Dimension Representation
pages.definition: Two-dimensional representations include sketches, drawings and paintings.
pages.benefits: Creating two-dimensional representations helps to highlight the structure or the "what" in a concept or big idea. In addition to familiarizing children with the details of the thing they are observing, this process helps children hone their scientific skills. It also provides a motivating way to practice and strengthen fine motor skills, which is especially beneficial for the youngest children.
pages.examples: Children create a drawing of a simple machine such as a pulley, then label all the parts and note the connections between the parts --the wheel, the axel and the rope linking the two.

video.title: Rocks and Sand and Awesome Scientists 2

planningPoints.text: With the foundation of the lesson planned in formal planning, the teacher asks children to make predictions and discuss them. This requires the teacher to use flexibility as she listens to children and builds on their ideas.

The children's predictions provide an assessment of their prior knowledge, which helps the teacher plan firsthand experiences related to the concepts. Later the children will use their predictions as references during and after conducting an experiment.

Although the teacher does not know what the children are going to say, she knows what the big idea is and chooses certain students' responses to either help highlight the learning goal or point out misconceptions. Notice, also, how she creates a rich and meaningful discussion by calling on children from different cultural and linguistic backgrounds and including both boys and girls.

setupPoints.text: The teacher works with a small group of children on the rug. They sit in a circle, which helps include everyone in the discussion.
Note that the representation and the experiment use simple materials such as marbles, sand, water, markers, and paper.

culturePoints.text: Notice how the teacher refers to the child as a scientist. This helps the child see herself as a scientist, which in turn builds confidence and competence.

Here the teacher helps a shy, quiet child feel safe explaining her work to her peers. She does this by letting the child finish her explanation even when it's inaudible to others, preventing other children from interrupting, and respectfully asking the child to repeat her explanation for the rest of the group.
Notice how the teacher calls attention to the concept by pausing the conversation and repeating the child's words to the group. This also reinforces the scientific lexicon.

Notice how the teacher makes an English Language learner feel comfortable discussing her ideas in front of her peers. She does this by calling on the child last, which gives the child time to observe others interacting with the teacher. The teacher also asks open-ended questions for which there is no wrong answer.

exPoints.text: The children have had prior experiences with sorting and categorizing solids by their properties, such as texture, weight, size and shape and by their characteristics, rough, heavy, small and round.

Making predictions and discussing them helps provide background knowledge that prepares children for the secondhand experience that will follow. This helps them become more selective in their observations of the secondhand experience and focuses their attention on the concept, which is matter takes up space.

repPoints.text: The teacher encourages the child to discuss her two dimensional representation. The child's response will help the teacher assess the student's understanding of the concept.
The children accompany their two dimensional representations with oral or textual representations or both.
Asking clarifying questions helps the teacher assess the child's understanding.
Repeating the child's words and asking a follow-up question reinforces a good observation and helps move the child forward in her understanding.

video.description: To provide children with background knowledge about the concept "matter takes up space," the teacher asked her students to predict what would happen to rocks in a jar when sand was poured on top of them. In this video, children have created drawings to illustrate their predictions and are gathered for a group discussion.
video.standards:
Materials come in different forms (states), including solids, liquids, and gases. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know solids, liquids, and gases have different properties.
  2. Students know the properties of substances can change when the substances are mixed, cooled, or heated.

enrich.intro: Before developing Thirdhand Experiences, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It is followed by discussion for assessment purposes
The children make revisions to their representations if needed
Children examine and talk about each others' representations
list.more: Children present their ideas for building a model of a LEGO factory in their classroom. As they talk, they refer to drawings that members of their planning group have created.

list.text: Children create multiple 2-D representations of each concept
Sometimes the children can choose the materials to use
Materials are limited to three or four choices
Students are not just copying a model
It is used with the other representational forms
list.more: A classroom display organizes children's multiple representations of the characteristics of matter. A variety of characteristics are represented in drawings and paintings as well as oral/textual and three-dimensional forms.

list.text: Assessment of the representation informs instruction

challenges.theText: What can I do if I'm only provided with traditional instructional materials?Teachers who want their students to develop skills in critical thinking and inquiry are restricted if they have only text-based materials that focus on memorizing facts and terminology. Curriculum is defined not only by the materials used but by what students are interested in, how they learn and on what they are assessed. Teachers can use the National Science Education Standards as a base to determine the concepts and big ideas they want students to know and then decide which materials they can use to help students reach those learning goals.What if I don't have a background in the arts? Will I still be able to teach this way?Understanding the importance of providing students with different ways to demonstrate their understanding matters far more than having a background in art. This is not to say it's not important for children to develop the art skills articulated in the National Standards, such as knowing the difference between materials, techniques and processes and using art materials and tools in a safe and responsible manner. However, it is equally important for children to be able to use the different media, techniques and processes to communicate ideas and concepts.How can I come up with ideas for children to represent their understanding in a variety of ways?Collaborating with colleagues who have strengths in different areas frequently promotes new ideas. In addition, students have ideas about creative ways to show what they know. The more accessible the materials are, the more eager students will be to experiment with them and the better adept they will become at choosing materials best suited to their understanding of the concepts.How do I use these kinds of representations as an assessment tool?Because children's representations reveal the gaps in their learning, they can help teachers know what experiences to plan based on what information is needed. Teachers can determine what knowledge children need to acquire by listening to the students talk about their representations, assessing their work and planning collaboratively to redefine the lessons to meet more specific goals.

pages.title: 3-Dimension Representation
pages.definition: Three-dimensional representations are structures or sculptures created with materials such as wood, clay, wire or blocks.
pages.benefits: Creating three-dimensional representations helps children make connections between the structure or "what" of a concept or big idea and its behavior or how it works. It also promotes deeper understanding of a concept by requiring children to explore the spatial relationships involved. In the creation of a drawing, these relationships are less important and harder to explore.
pages.examples: Children build a model of a simple machine such as a lever and label the parts of it (i.e., the "what"). Then, because it is a three-dimensional form, they can show how the lever is used to lift or pry an object (i.e., the "how"). Being able to show the function of the lever in addition to its structure helps children deepen their understanding of the concept that simple machines are devices that make work easier. Through trial and error they may also discover that where they put the fulcrum is crucial to getting their machine to operate.

video.title: The Roller Coaster 2

planningPoints.text: Planning for a project involves teachers deciding what materials will be needed to implement the children's ideas. In this example, the teacher also planned to have the students bring scrap materials in from home so that they would be available for use in building the roller coaster.

Students' interests, such as the need to support the ramp they are working on, can lead to effective ideas and projects that are related to the concepts. In fact, this entire roller coaster project was designed by the children to send messages between two classrooms.

Next you will hear the teacher struggling with the challenges inherent in planning which activities to monitor and which students to allow freedom in their work as she aims to have all of the students work productively.

setupPoints.text: The roller coaster has been mounted on the windows outside the classroom, making the outdoor space an extension of the learning environment. The model remains here while in progress so that the students can continually examine it and add to it as they learn more about the concepts being studied.
Materials consist of a variety of donated scraps such as chains, empty containers and blocks of wood. Using donated or found materials keeps project costs low and inspires ingenuity.
Materials for the project are readily accessible to the children so that they can easily experiment with them as they search for the best supplies to complete their model.

culturePoints.text: Although a teacher is present to supervise, the children are trusted to work on testing and improving the model roller coaster. They are able to work independently and productively because the teachers have set up routines to support this and children have had much practice working together.

Children work together, negotiating, discussing and planning. Having well-established social routines and offering frequent opportunities to collaborate help children develop and practice these skills.
When the children tell the teacher they need something to hold up the tubes, she doesn't solve the problem for them. She gives them encouragement to do the work on their own.

exPoints.text: Because this is a 3-D model, it is both conceptual and a firsthand experience where the students can see the issues involved in using simple machines such as ramps, and explore the concepts of force and motion. This experience can also lead to new conjectures about motion, such as when this student says, "when it goes slow, it stays just fine."

Having a firsthand experience with a model leads the students to new questions such as "Why does it [the ball] go down?" It also gives them tools to experiment and to attempt to find the answers to their questions.

repPoints.text: Building a 3-D structure such as a roller coaster provides a natural way to explore the properties of force and motion and kinetic and potential energy.
As the children repeatedly test their roller coaster they make revisions to help the message ball roll through one section more effectively.
In each representation different materials are offered. Here the children choose the materials. At other times the teacher makes the choice.

video.description: During their study of simple machines, force and motion, and kinetic and potential energy, students decided to build a roller coaster that sends messages from one classroom to another. In this video, two children are working on the roller coaster model.
video.standards:
The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background.
  2. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time.
  3. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull.
  4. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move.
  5. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

enrich.intro: Before developing Thirdhand Experiences, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It follows a 2-D representation
list.more: Two-dimensional representations allow children to compare images side by side. Fionn's drawing represents his understanding of inclined planes and how the angle of the incline affects the speed of a marble that is rolled from one end to the other.
list.moreTwo: Following their two-dimensional representations, children created three-dimensional representations, which highlight the structure of the inclined plane and the behavior of the marble as it rolls down the slope. Adil creates three-dimensional representations using a piece of wood and a marble.

list.text: It is followed by discussion for assessment purposes
list.more: Students have used their knowledge of the science concepts to build a robot that incorporates a variety of simple machines. After the initial phase of the building process, they gather on the rug for a discussion about which simple machines they used and why.
list.moreTwo: Throughout the discussion the group refers to a list of key words on the board. Following their discussion they work with the teacher to make modifications to their robot model.

list.text: Children make revisions to their representations if needed
Children examine and talk about each others' representations
Children create multiple 3-D representations of a concept
In each representation three or four different materials are offered
Sometimes the children choose the materials
Students are not just copying a model
It is used with the other representational forms
Assessment of the representation informs instruction

challenges.theText: What can I do if I'm only provided with traditional instructional materials?Teachers who want their students to develop skills in critical thinking and inquiry are restricted if they have only text-based materials that focus on memorizing facts and terminology. Curriculum is defined not only by the materials used but by what students are interested in, how they learn and on what they are assessed. Teachers can use the National Science Education Standards as a base to determine the concepts and big ideas they want students to know and then decide which materials they can use to help students reach those learning goals.What if I don't have a background in the arts? Will I still be able to teach this way?Understanding the importance of providing students with different ways to demonstrate their understanding matters far more than having a background in art. This is not to say it's not important for children to develop the art skills articulated in the National Standards, such as knowing the difference between materials, techniques and processes and using art materials and tools in a safe and responsible manner. However, it is equally important for children to be able to use the different media, techniques and processes to communicate ideas and concepts.How can I come up with ideas for children to represent their understanding in a variety of ways?Collaborating with colleagues who have strengths in different areas frequently promotes new ideas. In addition, students have ideas about creative ways to show what they know. The more accessible the materials are, the more eager students will be to experiment with them and the better adept they will become at choosing materials best suited to their understanding of the concepts.How do I use these kinds of representations as an assessment tool?Because children's representations reveal the gaps in their learning, they can help teachers know what experiences to plan based on what information is needed. Teachers can determine what knowledge children need to acquire by listening to the students talk about their representations, assessing their work and planning collaboratively to redefine the lessons to meet more specific goals.

pages.title: Kinesthetic Representation
pages.definition: Kinesthetic representations are created with body movement. They are used most often to help students learn concepts or big ideas that involve processes, movement or change, such as molecular movement in various states of matter, or the viscosities of different liquids.
pages.benefits: Using their bodies to demonstrate their understanding helps children make a personal connection to the concept or big idea. It also offers a way to get all children involved, including those who have a hard time sitting and those who struggle with fine motor or oral communication skills.
pages.examples: Children move their bodies to portray the motion of molecules in a solid, liquid and gas. Those acting like molecules in a gas bounce off of each other, dancing rapidly around the room. Children portraying molecules in a liquid glide together more slowly. Those portraying a solid huddle together, moving very little. Afterwards, teacher asks: "When you were acting like a molecule in a gas how did it feel? How was it different from when you were acting like a molecule in a solid?"

video.title: Make Your Body a Rough Piece of Wood

planningPoints.text: The teacher planned this additional experience with kinesthetic representation for children who needed reinforcement of their understanding of characteristics of solids.

The teacher makes decisions about which characteristics of solids she will model and which ones she will ask the children to model based on her learning goals for the children and to highlight important contrasts.

setupPoints.text: Ample space is provided for children to move around freely.
The teacher is using an empty auditorium for this lesson, but any space where children can move freely, such as part of a playground, would work.
The children are able to observe the teachers' representations from different angles.

culturePoints.text: Working with a small group of children creates a more immediate and intimate experience where all students have access to the teacher and the teacher can observe all the students.
When the teacher names the students and verbally acknowledges their work, she makes them feel included and encourages their participation.
Children are encouraged to observe each others' representations.

exPoints.text: Before creating kinesthetic representations, children have had experiences with the states of matter and developed a scientific lexicon to describe the properties and characteristics of solids, liquids and gases.

The teacher's model creates a secondhand experience for the children to see the characteristics of the solid. This could be a reminder of the expository and fictional texts containing words such as "pointy," "rough" and "smooth" that the children read previously.

repPoints.text: The teacher uses kinesthetic representation immediately following a discussion of words that describe some physical characteristics of matter.
The teacher reinforces the scientific lexicon by using it to describe what she sees.
Children are given the opportunity to observe other students' representations and to revise their own.

video.description: Children have spent time using their senses to experience the different states of matter and have developed a scientific lexicon to describe the properties and characteristics of solids, liquids, and gases. After representing each state of matter by sketching, sculpting with clay, and using the computer, the teacher asks her students to use their bodies to represent different characteristics of a solid.
video.standards:
Properties of materials can be observed, measured, and predicted. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know objects can be described in terms of the materials they are made of (e.g., clay, cloth, paper) and their physical properties (e.g., color, size, shape, weight, texture, flexibility, attraction to magnets, floating, sinking).

Materials come in different forms (states), including solids, liquids, and gases. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know solids, liquids, and gases have different properties.

enrich.intro: Before developing Thirdhand Experiences, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It is followed by discussion for assessment purposes
list.more: After each small group's kinesthetic representation of simple machines, the teacher asks the student audience, "What did you see? Which simple machines did this group represent?" The students representing the simple machine are asked to describe their process and talk about their machine and how it works. The discussion reveals a misunderstanding about how a spring in a wind-up toy builds up potential energy when a force is applied.

list.text: The teacher comments on things she sees happening
Children can make revisions to their representations if needed
list.more: Through discussion, a child who has created a kinesthetic representation of a spring in a wind-up toy realizes his body movements did not show energy building up as the spring coils. In his next attempt he revises his original representation. To show the build-up of energy, he waits while his partner represents winding the spring. He then jumps to show the release of energy.

list.text: Children create representations in a variety of groupings
Collaboration and negotiation are encouraged
list.more: Children work as a group to represent a machine using their bodies. They use their skills in collaboration and negotiation as they get their machine to "function."

list.text: Children are given the opportunity to create AND watch
It is used with the other representational forms
Assessment of the representation informs instruction

challenges.theText: What can I do if I'm only provided with traditional instructional materials?Teachers who want their students to develop skills in critical thinking and inquiry are restricted if they have only text-based materials that focus on memorizing facts and terminology. Curriculum is defined not only by the materials used but by what students are interested in, how they learn and on what they are assessed. Teachers can use the National Science Education Standards as a base to determine the concepts and big ideas they want students to know and then decide which materials they can use to help students reach those learning goals.What if I don't have a background in the arts? Will I still be able to teach this way?Understanding the importance of providing students with different ways to demonstrate their understanding matters far more than having a background in art. This is not to say it's not important for children to develop the art skills articulated in the National Standards, such as knowing the difference between materials, techniques and processes and using art materials and tools in a safe and responsible manner. However, it is equally important for children to be able to use the different media, techniques and processes to communicate ideas and concepts.How can I come up with ideas for children to represent their understanding in a variety of ways?Collaborating with colleagues who have strengths in different areas frequently promotes new ideas. In addition, students have ideas about creative ways to show what they know. The more accessible the materials are, the more eager students will be to experiment with them and the better adept they will become at choosing materials best suited to their understanding of the concepts.How do I use these kinds of representations as an assessment tool?Because children's representations reveal the gaps in their learning, they can help teachers know what experiences to plan based on what information is needed. Teachers can determine what knowledge children need to acquire by listening to the students talk about their representations, assessing their work and planning collaboratively to redefine the lessons to meet more specific goals.

pages.title: Oral-Textual Representation
pages.definition: Oral or textual representations include storytelling, song, creative drama or explanation.
pages.benefits: As children participate in discussions of concepts and big ideas they negotiate meaning and build an understanding of the curricular content. Oral explanations often lead to children building on and revising their thinking. Talking and writing about concepts offer important ways for children to increase their scientific lexicon and provide opportunities to use this lexicon in context. Also, children develop writing process skills that can be used to communicate with a variety of audiences and in all areas of the curriculum.
pages.examples: In writing a play about the life of a drop of water, children portray water changing from a liquid to a solid to a gas. Through the details of the story they explain why this change happens.

video.title: Water Wheels

planningPoints.text: Notice that the teacher's questions are planned to take advantage of what this type of representation is good at - namely, getting at why and how the water makes the water wheel move.
The teacher's original plan did not include focusing on water wheels. Children's interest provided an opportunity to make a meaningful connection with the concepts.
A strong knowledge of the content helps teachers assess students' conceptual understanding, correct their misperceptions and guide them to the learning goals.

setupPoints.text: Ample rug space allows the children to assemble comfortably for a discussion. By sitting low to the ground, the teacher conveys a sense of sharing rather than testing.
The teacher holds the book up and moves it around so that all the children can see it.

culturePoints.text: By posing a question and immediately saying, "Don't call out. Raise hands," the teacher creates an opportunity for children to think and gives everyone a chance to answer.
Asking, "What do you think?" offers the child a platform for discussing his ideas.
When the teacher asks if others agree with the student's idea, she helps build consensus but also leaves open the possibility for other thoughts.

exPoints.text: Ample rug space allows the children to assemble comfortably for a discussion. By sitting low to the ground, the teacher conveys a sense of sharing rather than testing.
Discussing prior experiences with water wheels helps build children's knowledge to create new understanding of the concepts.

repPoints.text: Discussing text offers children the opportunity to increase their scientific lexicon and practice using it in context. The child's statement that "water has gravity in it" provides an assessment of the child's understanding.
The teacher facilitates the discussion by pointing out key ideas that the children have brought up and connecting their ideas to the concepts.
Children have the opportunity to create new knowledge by building on their prior knowledge and experiences.

video.description: After children have had multiple opportunities to use their bodies to create force and motion on the playground, the teacher gathers her students on the rug to read a book about these concepts. A passage about water wheels prompts a discussion.
video.concept: Force causes motion, Simple machines make work easier
video.standards:
The motion of objects can be observed and measured. As a basis for understanding this concept:
  1. Students know the position of an object can be described by locating it in relation to another object or to the background.
  2. Students know an object's motion can be described by recording the change in position of the object over time.
  3. Students know the way to change how something is moving is by giving it a push or a pull. The size of the change is related to the strength, or the amount of force, of the push or pull.
  4. Students know tools and machines are used to apply pushes and pulls (forces) to make things move.
  5. Students know objects fall to the ground unless something holds them up.

enrich.intro: Before developing Thirdhand Experiences, consider that children will get the most out of this Component when it has the following properties:

list.text: It is used with the other representational forms
list.more: Fionn has used text and drawings to represent his understanding of inclined planes and how the angle of the incline affects the speed of a marble that is rolled from one end to the other. The drawings allow him to show contrast between two scenarios involving planes with different slopes. The text provides a way to explain why the marble travels at greater speed when it is rolled down the first plane. Both representations provide the teacher with an assessment of Fionn's understanding of the concepts.

list.text: Students are given multiple opportunities to discuss their work
The teacher facilitates discussion and helps children connect ideas
Discussion builds on prior experiences and knowledge
Assessment of the representation informs instruction
